articles.headline: ‘Energy Shots’ Stimulate Power Drink Sales
articles.snippet: Sales of two-ounce “energy shots” with a concentrated dose of caffeine are soaring in the middle of a recession.
articles.abstract: Sales of two-ounce “energy shots” with a concentrated dose of caffeine are soaring in the middle of a recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLLEGE PARK, Md.  The power drink of the moment costs 20 times as much per ounce as Coca-Cola, comes in a tiny bottle and tastes so bad that most people hold their noses and down it in a single gulp.

articles.headline: U.S. Inaction Seen After Taliban P.O.W.’s Died
articles.snippet: Bush administration officials are said to have repeatedly discouraged efforts to investigate a 2001 mass killing in Afghanistan by the forces of a U.S.-backed warlord.
articles.abstract: Bush administration officials are said to have repeatedly discouraged efforts to investigate a 2001 mass killing in Afghanistan by the forces of a U.S.-backed warlord.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  After a mass killing of hundreds, perhaps thousands, of Taliban prisoners of war by the forces of an American-backed warlord during the 2001 invasion of Afghanistan, Bush administration officials repeatedly discouraged efforts to investigate the episode, according to government officials and human rights organizations.

articles.headline: U.S. Wiretapping of Limited Value, Officials Report
articles.snippet: A government review said the effectiveness of the Bush administration’s program of wiretapping without warrants was unclear in the fight against terrorism.
articles.abstract: A government review said the effectiveness of the Bush administration’s program of wiretapping without warrants was unclear in the fight against terrorism.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  While the Bush administration had defended its program of wiretapping without warrants as a vital tool that saved lives, a new government review released Friday said the program’s effectiveness in fighting terrorism was unclear.
articles.byline: By Eric Lichtblau and James Risen

articles.headline: When the Fledglings Return to the Nest
articles.snippet: It’s a quandary that Dr. Spock didn’t address: How should parents handle adult children coming back home to live?
articles.abstract: It’s a quandary that Dr. Spock didn’t address: How should parents handle adult children coming back home to live?
articles.lead_paragraph: The boomerang kids, grown-ups who come home to live with their parents anyway, are having their cultural moment.

articles.headline: Collect Now, or Later? Timing Your Social Security Benefits
articles.snippet: Waiting until full retirement age or even later to collect benefits can result in a larger check — but sometimes collecting early makes more sense.
articles.abstract: Waiting until full retirement age or even later to collect benefits can result in a larger check — but sometimes collecting early makes more sense.
articles.lead_paragraph: Collecting Social Security as soon as you are eligible is a tempting proposition  but experts agree you should try to resist if you can.

articles.headline: From Treasury to Banks, an Ultimatum on Mortgage Relief
articles.snippet: The federal government is taking the largest mortgage servicers to the woodshed on their efforts to modify shaky loans.
articles.abstract: The federal government is taking the largest mortgage servicers to the woodshed on their efforts to modify shaky loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Remember that infamous meeting last October at the Treasury Department, the one where then-Secretary Henry Paulson locked the chief executives of the nation’s nine largest financial institutions in a room, and wouldn’t let them out until they agreed to accept billions of dollars in government bailout money  whether they wanted it or not?

articles.headline: Tight Mortgage Rules Exclude Even Good Risks
articles.snippet: How can the housing market recover, economists ask, if so few buyers qualify for mortgages under rigid new rules?
articles.abstract: How can the housing market recover, economists ask, if so few buyers qualify for mortgages under rigid new rules?
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON  Inna Komarovskaya was ready to do her part to revive the economy: She found a “really cute” condo to buy.

articles.headline: A Strongman Is China’s Rock in Ethnic Strife
articles.snippet: Wang Lequan, who has used an iron hand against Uighur Muslims, is Beijing’s go-to expert on policies toward ethnic minorities.
articles.abstract: Wang Lequan, who has used an iron hand against Uighur Muslims, is Beijing’s go-to expert on policies toward ethnic minorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  As ethnic Han gangs roamed the streets of Urumqi on Tuesday at dusk, seeking revenge against Muslim Uighur rioters who killed scores of Han two nights earlier, a balding Communist Party bureaucrat abruptly appeared on the city’s television screens to call for calm.

articles.headline: Obama Delivers Call for Change to a Rapt Africa
articles.snippet: President Obama traveled in Africa as a potent symbol of a new era but also as a messenger with a theme of responsibility.
articles.abstract: President Obama traveled in Africa as a potent symbol of a new era but also as a messenger with a theme of responsibility.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAPE COAST, Ghana  President Obama traveled in his father’s often-troubled home continent on Saturday, where he symbolized a new political era but brought a message of tough love: American aid must be matched by Africa’s responsibility for its own problems.

articles.headline: Path to Supreme Court: Speak Capably, Say Little
articles.snippet: Supreme Court candidates have learned how to avoid answers that could scuttle their nominations.
articles.abstract: Supreme Court candidates have learned how to avoid answers that could scuttle their nominations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  On his first day at the Justice Department in 1981, a 26-year-old lawyer named John G. Roberts Jr. was handed a high-profile assignment: to help prepare Sandra Day O’Connor, then an Arizona judge, for her Supreme Court confirmation hearings.

articles.headline: President Urges Public Patience on Economy
articles.snippet: President Obama said his plan had saved the economy from collapse and put it on a gradual course to recovery.
articles.abstract: President Obama said his plan had saved the economy from collapse and put it on a gradual course to recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama is stepping up efforts to maintain public support for his agenda as rising unemployment presents him with the biggest test of his political strength since taking office.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Carl Hulse

articles.headline: How to Start a Company (and Kiss Like Angelina)
articles.snippet: Success making how-to videos takes more than a bunch of short clips. On the Internet, part of the trick is having a distinct personality.
articles.abstract: Success making how-to videos takes more than a bunch of short clips. On the Internet, part of the trick is having a distinct personality.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN their star turns in James Bond movies, Ursula Andress and Halle Berry perfected the art of emerging from an ocean swim and walking onto the beach in a dripping-wet bikini.

articles.headline: A Call to Jihad, Answered in America
articles.snippet: The F.B.I. is looking into a group of Somali-Americans who are the focus of what may be the most significant domestic terrorism investigation since Sept. 11.
articles.abstract: The F.B.I. is looking into a group of Somali-Americans who are the focus of what may be the most significant domestic terrorism investigation since Sept. 11.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS  The Carlson School of Management rises from the asphalt like a monument to capitalist ambition. Stock prices race across an electronic ticker near a sleek entrance and the atrium soars skyward, as if lifting the aspirations of its students. The school’s plucky motto is “Nowhere but here.”

articles.headline: No Stork Involved, but Mom and Dad Had Help
articles.snippet: The parents of children born to surrogates wrestle with a modern twist on the old question: Where did I come from?
articles.abstract: The parents of children born to surrogates wrestle with a modern twist on the old question: Where did I come from?
articles.lead_paragraph: Melissa Brisman and her daughter, Simmie, age 6, were catching a matinee of “Marley and Me” in Tenafly, N.J.

articles.headline: Looking for the Lenders’ Little Helpers
articles.snippet: Some experts see a rising receptiveness by some courts to hold giant institutions that helped mortgage lenders finance toxic loans legally responsible.
articles.abstract: Some experts see a rising receptiveness by some courts to hold giant institutions that helped mortgage lenders finance toxic loans legally responsible.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT is hard not to be dismayed by the fact that two years into our economic crisis so few perpetrators of financial misdeeds have been held accountable for their actions. That so many failed mortgage lenders do not appear to face any legal liability for the role they played in almost blowing up the economy really rankles. They have simply moved on to the next “opportunity.”

articles.headline: A Happy Family of 8,000, but for How Long?
articles.snippet: As demand recedes, a family-owned business where layoffs have been almost unheard of faces the possibility of cutbacks.
articles.abstract: As demand recedes, a family-owned business where layoffs have been almost unheard of faces the possibility of cutbacks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ditzingen, Germany

articles.headline: Cheney Is Linked to Concealment of C.I.A. Project
articles.snippet: The C.I.A. was said to have withheld information about a secret counterterrorism program from Congress for eight years on orders from the former vice president.
articles.abstract: The C.I.A. was said to have withheld information about a secret counterterrorism program from Congress for eight years on orders from the former vice president.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Central Intelligence Agency withheld information about a secret counterterrorism program from Congress for eight years on direct orders from former Vice President Dick Cheney, the agency’s director, Leon E. Panetta, has told the Senate and House intelligence committees, two people with direct knowledge of the matter said Saturday.

articles.headline: UBS and Prosecutors Seek Hearing Delay
articles.snippet: The Swiss bank and U.S. federal prosecutors are trying to settle a dispute over the release of names of bank clients suspected of offshore tax evasion.
articles.abstract: The Swiss bank and U.S. federal prosecutors are trying to settle a dispute over the release of names of bank clients suspected of offshore tax evasion.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Swiss bank UBS and United States federal prosecutors sought on Sunday to delay a hearing scheduled for Monday so the two sides could try to settle their closely watched dispute over the release of names of wealthy American clients of the bank who are suspected of offshore tax evasion.

articles.headline: Tamils Now Languish in Sri Lanka Camps
articles.snippet: Hundreds of thousands of Tamils are being held because the government believes former rebels may be hiding among them.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of thousands of Tamils are being held because the government believes former rebels may be hiding among them.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHEDDIKULAM, Sri Lanka  When the piercing whistle and sharp thuds of artillery shells grew faint, S. Theventhran dashed to safety.

articles.headline: For Goldman, a Swift Return to Lofty Profits
articles.snippet: Goldman Sachs, which only recently repaid its bailout money, is expected to report big profits on Tuesday.
articles.abstract: Goldman Sachs, which only recently repaid its bailout money, is expected to report big profits on Tuesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: Most of Wall Street, and America, is still waiting for an economic recovery. Then there is Goldman Sachs.
articles.byline: By Graham Bowley and Jenny Anderson

articles.headline: Approval by a Blogger May Please a Sponsor
articles.snippet: When a blogger recommends a product a company has handed her or him, how much disclosure are readers owed? Even the Federal Trade Commission wonders.
articles.abstract: When a blogger recommends a product a company has handed her or him, how much disclosure are readers owed? Even the Federal Trade Commission wonders.
articles.lead_paragraph: Colleen Padilla, a 33-year-old mother of two who lives in suburban Philadelphia, has reviewed nearly 1,500 products, including baby clothes, microwave dinners and the Nintendo Wii, on her popular Web site Classymommy.com. Her site attracts 60,000 unique visitors every month, and Ms. Padilla attracts something else: free items from companies eager to promote their products to her readers.

articles.headline: With a Little ‘True Blood,’ HBO Is Reviving Its Fortunes
articles.snippet: A series about vampires appears to be pulling the channel out of a dry spell that began when several hit shows like “The Sopranos” ended.
articles.abstract: A series about vampires appears to be pulling the channel out of a dry spell that began when several hit shows like “The Sopranos” ended.
articles.lead_paragraph: The slump at HBO is apparently over.

articles.headline: In Japan, Machines for Work and Play Are Idle
articles.snippet: As consumers cut spending, Japan’s robots, the world’s largest fleet of mechanized workers, are falling still.
articles.abstract: As consumers cut spending, Japan’s robots, the world’s largest fleet of mechanized workers, are falling still.
articles.lead_paragraph: KITAKYUSHU, Japan  They may be the most efficient workers in the world. But in the global downturn, they are having a tough time finding jobs.

articles.headline: Study Measures the Chatter of the News Cycle
articles.snippet: Findings suggested traditional news sites were typically ahead of blogs by two and a half hours when a story line spread.
articles.abstract: Findings suggested traditional news sites were typically ahead of blogs by two and a half hours when a story line spread.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the most part, the traditional news outlets lead and the blogs follow, typically by 2.5 hours, according to a new computer analysis of news articles and commentary on the Web during the last three months of the 2008 presidential campaign.

articles.headline: Obama Faces a New Push to Look Back
articles.snippet: There is new pressure on the president to ramp up investigations of Bush-era security programs, despite the political risks.
articles.abstract: There is new pressure on the president to ramp up investigations of Bush-era security programs, despite the political risks.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama is facing new pressure to reverse himself and to ramp up investigations into the Bush-era security programs, despite the political risks.

articles.headline: Palin’s Long March to a Short-Notice Resignation
articles.snippet: Interviews show that a seemingly relentless string of professional and personal troubles led to Sarah Palin’s surprise resignation as governor of Alaska.
articles.abstract: Interviews show that a seemingly relentless string of professional and personal troubles led to Sarah Palin’s surprise resignation as governor of Alaska.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article was reported by Jim Rutenberg from New York and Serge F. Kovaleski from Wasilla and Anchorage, Alaska. Jo Becker reported from New York and Kim Severson and William Yardley from Wasilla and Anchorage.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Serge F. Kovaleski
